title: Tired of flying halfway round the world and back for a half-hour meeting? Time to blur the lines between work and travel
text:
CNN Leadership
Bleisure travelers: A new tribe injects fun into business trips By Milena Veselinovic , for CNN Updated 0752 GMT (1452 HKT) October 13, 2015 15 photos: 1. United States – A new breed of traveler is mixing business with leisure on so-called "bleisure" trips. But where are they splashing the cash? The Global Business Travel Association (GBTA) has published the ranking of the top 15 markets for business travel spending . In first place is the U.S. where $288.4 billion was spent on business travel in 2014. Hide Caption 1 of 15 15 photos: 2. China – GBTA says that business travel spending in China is set to increase by 61% in the coming years, from $261 billion in 2014 to $420 billion in 2019. Kunming, the capital of Yunnan Province -- known as the "Spring City" because of its weather -- is a good choice for a bleisure vacation. Hide Caption 2 of 15 15 photos: 3. Japan – Japan's total business travel spending in 2014 was $61.5 billion. The country's employees work notoriously long hours, with many putting in as many as 80 in a week . Time for a leisure break along a Kyoto canal, we reckon. Hide Caption 3 of 15 15 photos: 4. Germany – It's not just attractions like Berlin's Brandenburg Gate that draw visitors to Germany. The country ranks fourth for business travel spending. Hide Caption 4 of 15 15 photos: 5. United Kingdon – The UK government states that employees can't work more than 48 hours a week , although it's possible to opt out of that restriction. If you're traveling to London for work, there should still be time to visit the Houses of Parliament. Hide Caption 5 of 15 15 photos: 6. France – In 2000, France introduced a 35-hour work week to encourage companies to hire more people. Parisians have the most relaxed working schedule in the world according to a UBS report, leaving them plenty of time to visit the picturesque Queyras Castle (pictured) near the French Alps for business or pleasure. Hide Caption 6 of 15 15 photos: 7. South Korea – Spending on business travel in South Korea grew by 3.9% in 2014. The capital Seoul is a popular conference destination and those flying in and out of it can find decent shopping even at Incheon International Airport, named world's best airport several times. Hide Caption 7 of 15 15 photos: 8. Brazil – Latin American business travel spending totaled $52 billion in 2014, and was led by Brazil with $32 billion spent. As host of next summer's Olympic Games the country will see a flood of visitors who are bound to combine work and pleasure. Hide Caption 8 of 15 15 photos: 9. Italy – Travelers in Western Europe spent $271 billion on business trips in 2014, with Italy accounting for $30.9 billion. With cities like Venice (pictured) a short flight or train ride away, a work trip can quickly turn into a cultural adventure. Hide Caption 9 of 15 15 photos: 10. India – India is poised for breakout growth in business travel spending according to the GBTA. In 2014, it accounted for $26 billion. Experts say that 15 years from now the country will likely be a top-five market. Hide Caption 10 of 15 15 photos: 11. Canada – Travelers in North America spent $318 billion on business travel in 2014, with 90% coming from the U.S., while Mexico and Canada generated the remaining 10%. Hide Caption 11 of 15 15 photos: 12. Russia – Russia may be in the top 15 countries for business travel spending, but last year growth fell -6.7%. The State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg was recently ranked sixth best museum in the world by TripAdvisor. Hide Caption 12 of 15 15 photos: 13. Australia – After the monotony of business meetings, travelers in Australia can take time off to see Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park, home to one of the largest sandstone monoliths in the world. Hide Caption 13 of 15 15 photos: 14. Spain – Spending on business travel in Spain went up 6.8% last year. With sites like Gaudi's Park Guell in Barcelona (pictured) it's not hard to see why visitors would want to stick around. Hide Caption 14 of 15 15 photos: 15. Netherlands – With its colorful fields of tulips, the Netherlands attracts plenty of tourists, but total business travel spending for last year also came to a whopping $17.8 billion. Hide Caption
